ObjTextEntries.textEntry:
For DOJ competition details, see Bulletin 2, pages 8-10.

 

The series of murals collectively titled the Search for Truth were completed in 1939 and installed in the Law Library of the Department of Justice building in 1941.  The fourteen individual murals and two triptychs (a painting consisting of three parts) depict man's struggle for justice and trace the historic tools he has used in this pursuit. Although his commission was well received by the Section of Painting and Sculpture, the hanging of the 20 panels was delayed due to the objections of a Roman Catholic cleric.  Sterne believed these to be his finest work and was incensed at the charges against the panel "Cruelty".  The cleric maintained that the panel appeared to have clergy aiding in acts of cruelty rather than halting trial by ordeal. Through the efforts of Edward Bruce (Treasury Department) and Biddle the affair was resolved and the paintings were eventually hung. Several source documents indicate that Sterne nearly went broke paying the performance bonds on this work during the controversy.

BRUTE FORCE
This panel represents the most primitive manner of settling disputes, as superior strength triumphs over true Justice.  The animal nature of this type of action is suggested by the tiger in the upper right corner, protectively guarding a freshly killed sheep.


This panel shows in the foreground two men struggling, the flock of sheep on the right suggesting the property over which they are fighting, while the mountain lion holding down his doomed prey suggests the unequal struggle in the animal kingdom.

GREED
In this scene, a group of Roman soldiers are shown casting dice for the garments of Christ.  The soldiers are so consumed by their greed, they fail to notice the dove of peace who hovers near the foot of the cross and Christ's crucified feet.

 

This panel shows a group fighting over and casting dice for the garments of Jesus at the foot of the Cross, oblivious of the drama which is taking place above. 


CRUELTY/ORDEAL

This panel generated controversy for its depiction of a man undergoing a trial by fire surrounded by a group of monks.  This ancient and superstitious mode of trial was banned by the Catholic Church in 1215 and the white-robed figure at the far right of the composition represents Pope Innocent III (1198-1216) who facilitated its elimination.  The Pope's gesture is meant both to convey a blessing upon the victim and to show his distaste for the barbaric practice.  Some officials in the Church objected to this depiction of clerics as they feared it would wrongly associate the Church as a whole with this obsolete practice.

 

This panel shows trial by fire; man carrying two red hot irons collapsing at the altar where he is supposed to place them after having walked three paces.  The Pope giving his blessing to the victim put a stop to this cruelty. Tthe hanging of the 20 panels was delayed due to the objections of a Roman Catholic cleric. The cleric maintained that the panel appeared to have clergy aiding in acts of cruelty rather than halting trial by ordeal. Through the efforts of Edward Bruce (Treasury Department) and Biddle the affair was resolved and the paintings were eventually hung. Several source documents indicate that Sterne nearly went broke paying the performance bonds on this work during the controversy.

JUSTICE TEMPERED BY MERCY


Sterne used this subject to illustrate Jesus' famous admonition to his followers "he who is without sin should cast the first stone," and two framing figures can be seen clutching stones in their fists.  On closer inspection, it also becomes apparent that Sterne constructed the entire composition as a mirror, with the two flanking female figures and central male figure reflected.  It is possible that the artist intended to inspire introspection, causing viewers to ponder their daily interactions with others.

 

 

 

 

This panel illustrates "He who is without sin should cast the first stone".  We see the reflections of the figures in the foreground as if in a pool and on the scales, an eye for an eye. 

INTOLERANCE


This panel depicts a Roman scene in which books are being burned.  In the foreground, a figure collapses on top of the books as he is covered with tar by a masked figure.  At the prostrate man's feet, another figure fans the flames with a bellows.  The face of the brutish Emperor who is surrounded by Roman soldiers, is thought to have been based on Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini.

 

This panel shows an old Roman scene.  Figure collapsed over a book besmirched with tar.  Man setting fire to the group.  Background, a dictator surrounded by Roman soldiers. 

TRADITION


This composition contrasts the constructive and destructive elements of tradition.  The central woman holding two babies is a nurturing and maternal figure.  However, she is engulfed by the rib cage of a skeleton, signifying the past, and threatened by the weapons of the figures to her right, representing Roman, Medieval, and Modern soldiers.  To her left are Hammurabi, Moses, and Justinian, important figures in law throughout the ages, whose practices of the constructive nature of the law counter the destruction caused by war.

 

This panel shows a woman nursing two babies inside of a skeleton.  To the left, Hammurabi, Moses and Justinian.  To the right, a Roman, Medieval, and Modern soldier.  One of twenty mural panels for the Library. 

SUPERSTITION


In this panel Sterne depicts the swooning Delphic Sibyl caught in a trance and surrounded by her attendants and frightened onlookers.  The Sibyls, ancient pagan priestesses, recorded their prophecies in books that were believed to herald both the coming of Christ and events in his life.  The Delphic Sibyl is usually accompanied by her attribute, a crown of thorns, as she foresaw Christ's martyrdom on the cross.  One of the figures to her right is writing on a scroll, perhaps recording her newest vision. In the background a priest-like figure holds a knife over a female sacrifice.

 

This panel shows the Delphic Sybil in a trance, surrounded by attendants.  In the background is a sacrifice.

 

CONTINUITY OF THE LAW

 

 This panel is part of a triptych showing "The Law" in the center panel seated over the earth with a scroll which flows into the adjoining panels.  Behind the figure are two others. 

 

This panel is part of a tryptich (representing the continuity of the law) with "The Law" sitting in the center panel.  The figure on her right holding part of a scroll represents the future. The figure on the left represents the past. 

AMBITION


The central figures represent Jacob and the angel he encountered as he attempted to cross the Jordan River. The pair's wrestling match often symbolizes the Christian's physical struggle on earth, but in this mural Sterne choose to present a more spiritual and mysterious dream encounter with less focus on the physicality of the incident.  The people scrambling up the rocks that frame the composition represent earthly ambition.

 

This panel shows Jacob wrestling with the Angels, surrounded by people climbing up a rock representing earthly ambition.


ENVIRONMENT


This panel emphasizes how important environment is in producing a just society, spotlighting two young children who witness the holdup of a wealthy couple by an armed man.  The central reclining woman offers flowers to the gunman, as if attempting to trade his weapon for the blossoms.  In the bottom right corner, a young newsboy sells the "Yellow Gazette," which is likely a reference to the irresponsible, inaccurate, and exploitative reporting known as "yellow journalism" that had become widespread around the turn of the century.

 

This panel shows children witnessing a hold-up.  Sob sister handing flowers to a criminal.  At the right, a news boy with "Daily Yellow Gazette" in his hands. 



RED TAPE


A large red spider web marked with Roman numerals and radiating from a central skull with clock hands suggests the oppressively complex and time-consuming nature of bureaucracy.  Tormented figures await rescue by Supreme Court Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes (1902-1932) who sits astride a white charger, Don Quixote-like, his lance aimed at the web, ready to cut through the "red tape" that is preventing justice from being served.

 

This panel shows a huge spider web around animal's skull.  Clock suggests passage of time.  People caught in this net being released by Don Quixote. 

 

SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATION
(JUSTICE AND SCIENCE)


This panel illustrates how the pursuit of justice is facilitated by science.  On the right side of the composition a kidnapping is in progress.  However, the investigators at left are in the process of solving the crime using forensic evidence.  The central figure illuminates fingerprints, indicating the evidence that a criminal leaves behind.  This improvement in scientific crime detection was due in large part to the growing power of the Federal Bureau of Investigation during the twenties and thirties.  The first FBI crime laboratory was established in 1932 and forensic science was increasingly utilized as a result.

This panel shows central figure holding a lens which throws light on a finger print card.  At right is a kidnapping.  At left, criminal in a barber shop being manicured. 

FALSE WITNESS


In this panel Sterne presents a dishonest witness as he is unmasked.   The man attempts to hide his deceitful testimony behind the "honest" face he presents to the court.  However, he is revealed by the allegorical figure of Truth who collapses before the "false witness" and the judge who covers his face with his hand in despair.  At the far right of the composition, the figure of Bribery covers its face and holds out a rolled bill.  Bribery's position behind the man indicates its influence on his unjust actions.   The central presence of a floating bible also suggests that the witness' testimony is "unsupported" by truth.

 

This panel shows a man delivering an oath on the Bible.  He has two faces, one a sweet honest mask, the other hiding behind it; figure of Bribery behind the man. 


COMPETITION AND MONOPOLY


Sterne depicted two men locked in a central tug-of-war whose actions are mirrored by two steers who lock horns in the background.  In the foreground, a figure strong arms his competitors, forcing them to surrender to him and suggesting the negative repercussions of allowing one individual to retain exclusive control and possession over a commodity or service.  The very strong horizontal movement of these figures creates a tension integral to the composition.

 

BELIEF IN MAGIC


At the far left of this panel, a well-dressed magician pulls a rabbit from a hat with one hand while the other unfurls a ticker tape.  The tape takes the form of the Pied Piper, who entices a group of working class people to follow him.  One man holds a bank envelope, indicating his willingness to surrender his savings to the magician who promises what he cannot deliver.

 

This panel shows a magician making a piper figure out of ticker tape. The piper is followed by people entranced by speculation.  Gamblers are in the foreground. 

ATTRIBUTES OF JUSTICE

This panel is the central panel of a tryptich.  It shows the "Scale of Justice" flanked by reapers with sowers behind them suggesting the inevitability between cause and effect. 

This panel is the right hand panel of a tryptich entitled "Attributes of Justice".  Man crouched down and resting on one knee, holding the end of a scroll

This panel is the left hand side of a tryptich entitled "Attributes of Justice".  Nude with a cloth behind her.  One of twenty mural panels for the Library.

THE FOUR FUNDAMENTAL FORMS OF MAN'S DEVELOPMENT OF THE IDEA OF JUSTICE
